statements.statement: Physician-patients often give unwarranted or unhelpful recommendations or advice regarding their own care.
Consults or appointments with physician-patients take less time than with non-physician patients.
Physician-patients are more demanding than non-physician patients.
Physician-patients consume fewer resources than non-physician patients.
Physician-patients require fewer visits and less follow-up than non-physician patients.
Physician-patients are often more grateful and reasonable than the average patient.
I feel more pressured when treating patients who are physicians.
When presenting as a patient to another physician, I feel pressured to be a "good" patient.
I feel I heal faster, or recover quicker from illnesses than many of my patients.
Physician-patients skip routine screening with greater frequency than non-physician patients.
Physicians treating me appear to use out-of-date evidence in my treatments.
Physician-patients often arrive in the late stages of their disease.
Physician-patients require less explanation than non-physician patients in the discussion of their diagnosis.
Physician-patients often like to get technical with discussions of treatment options.
Physician-patients have an educated opinion on their treatment options.
I probably trouble my physicians less than their average patient.
